pros: Great hospital to work for, no cons
cons: There are no cons absolutely great hospital to work in

review_title: You Learn a Lot But at What Price
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Charleston, SC
pros: As my first job out of college I learned a lot about taking vitals, helping with wound care, and how a hospital functions. It has forced me to be extremely good with time management and to not get too emotional in an extremely stressful environment.
cons: You never know what you’re going to get. Some days you may have 8 patients and other days you can have 12 total care patients (14 is the highest for me). It’s extremely disappointing when I can’t give a patient the care they deserve on those extra busy days. Management is also a huge issue. I have never seen a charge nurse, DON, or CCO last more than 6-8 months. With management constantly changing, messages often get mixed and it’s hard to know what will actually be implemented long term. Additionally, I have seen coworkers be homophobic and transphobic towards other coworkers with zero repercussions.

job_title: Physical Therapist in Bowling Green, KY
pros: Good mentorship with great opportunity to learn as new graduate, Good therapy management, Caseload of 6 patient care hours a day
cons: Low pay, 2% annual raises with increased top out time, no upward mobility from therapy staff, increased responsibility with no increase in pay

review_title: Get in, stay for a year, get out
pros: Worked at the western billing office, not San Joaquin Rehab. Pay is slightly above market ($1-2 per hour.) Initially worked as a temporary employee through an agency (AppleOne) before transitioning to a full time employee. Can't remember the hourly rate offhand but think I started at $21-22 per hour at the time. Received a $1-$2 "promotion" after 9 months. Take note that if you are a temporary employee, Vibra typically pays the agency 1.30x of your hourly rate. Good to know if you're looking to negotiate a temp to hire deal. If you're going for an entry level gig in accounting, or finance this isn't a bad place to start. Expect day to day activities to be archaic and administrative, with zero exposure to anything strategic. Leverage automation (Advanced Excel functions, macros, ChatGpt) early on to open up your capacity and position yourself for the next job by listening to books, podcasts or learning other hard skills. High probability that you'll trauma bond with line employees and low tier management. Walked away with some great friendships from here.
cons: If you're mid-career and you are considering a low/middle management role jere, I'm very sorry that you're in this position. Again, the work is mundane. You'll hit a point roughly 6 months in where you won't get exposed to much else from a hard skill perspective. What you will learn is the intricacies of managing/dealing with low quality and/or toxic people at all levels. Which will help later in your career. There are hardly any growth opportunities. Only time I ever witnessed management turnover was 1) reactivate to firings and 2) filling of immediate needs due to a merger/acquisition of Ernest Health facilities. Physical paper is the name of the game. Meaning you print work papers, compile/annotate and rescan into a filing database for almost everything. Ton of wasted time but this may have changed during COVID to accommodate remote work. The con of cons is toxic management. Never have I witnessed such pettiness and lack of empathy anywhere. Think the saddest thing I saw was the layoff of an employee who gave 30 years of her life to the company probably because some spreadsheet indicated that it was the right thing to do. In any case, the toxicity is something you would expect in high-finance or tech where the compensation justifies, not an enterprise stuck in 2003 in both operation and compensation.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Rancho Mirage, CA
pros: 1. Salary is comparable to the nearby big facilities. 2. Workload is not too bad compared to other Rehab facilities. 3. Great teamwork 4. Free lunch
cons: 1. High staff turnover 2. Pt census are seasonal. Not a perfect place for full time job.

review_title: You will learn a lot working there
pros: They have a good CNO
cons: Hard work and low staff

pros: Co-workers were amazing. Enjoyed helping the patients I could.
cons: This place is an abusive relationship. I have never been treated so poorly or degraded by upper management at any job as I was here. They are greedy, selfish, and have zero concerns for their employees. Turnover is high because nobody can handle the stress. They refuse to look at the real issues with the facility and continue to point the fingers at staff, choosing a new person to blame any minute they can. This has gone on for years and things never improve. Shocking to me that this place is privately owned, which tells me all I need to know about the owner. Facilities nearby send patients hours out of their way to other facilities. It is an absolute disaster.

cons: Toxic HR leadership and lack of accountability; The HR leadership group that is expected to lead cultural values and support staff, are quite literally the worst I’ve ever worked with; Narcissistic leadership starting at the tippy top.

Explains why turnover is incredibly high.

review_title: Quickest I have ever left a job…
pros: Pay, scheduling, and close to home.
cons: I would only recommend this corp to other RNs for high dollar agency pay or if you have stuff on your license and can’t work anywhere else. I didn’t even last four hours here. This broke my personal record of the quickest I have ever quit a job. It was easily the worst place I have ever worked and the pay was not worth the disrespect. After three hours of the most demeaning and groveling training experience, My “I’m outta here moment” was when my preceptor started  a ten minute lecture on how to prime an IV. By that point, it wasn’t even worth the money to me anymore. A few of the “tenured” RNs are there for a reason. That reason being, a more competitive workplace would never tolerate their bullying behavior. Management is oblivious and seems to just want to stay employed at any cost. I feel so grateful I don’t have to see these people ever again. Even though I didn’t even spend four hours on the floor, it appeared to be a dysfunctional environment for RNs due to current staff. My preceptor told me I didn’t belong in this type of work after 2.5 hours of one patient care. I was bored out of my mind.  I have  been a clinically practicing nurse since 2004. I was impressed by the LPNs and PCT. I felt sorry for them having to answer to nurses I met there. Management of course gets a big thumbs down. - heavily redacted so Glassdoor would approve. This is a much nicer version of what I’d really like to tell you.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse (LPN) in New Bedford, MA
pros: The flexibility of hours plus time is always available.
cons: One con is the absence of a nurse manager, CUL or charge nurse per unit/per shift so that when an important issue arises it can have immediate attention. Just having one manager (CUL) for the entire hospital during the day is not efficient nor safe for staff and patients. Additionally, the manager has to periodically work on a team of 5-8 patients all while still working as the CUL/manager. This is all due to understaffed CNAs and Nurses. The situation is not a post-covid issue. It is the typical situation for many years. All staff with a license in the building need to help on the units when staff is lacking.

job_title: Corporate Staff Accountant in Mechanicsburg, PA
pros: I had a paycheck twice a month.
cons: Where do I start? There is not ample training, tons of work without direction, poor leadership all the way to the top. HR is a joke, they never took any of the bulling complaints about management seriously because they were personal relationships that trumped L&I laws and regs. They make a big deal when you join the cult then once your are there a week, the abuse starts. I cannot believe someone hasn't sued them. Then there is the Medicare fraud issue that was still going on when I left in 2019. If you have self-worth and integrity this place isn't for you. If you just need a check and can handle being mistreated then go for it. At best it is just to a job/paycheck until you can find a good place to work. One review said to keep your head down, mouth shut and just work...that is soo true.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Lincoln Park, MI
pros: Competitive pay and 12hr shifts
cons: Consistently short staffed and high employee turnover. Vibra boosts a 4:1 pt to nursing ratio.   A 6:1 ratio is the norm and it not based on pt acutity.  Often nurses have to do complete pt care despite having 6pts because they can't keep their  cena/ pcts. Management is unsympathetic and will just keep taking more admissions even though they do not have the staff to care for them.  Nurses are also expected to work "hard to fill holidays"  (Mother's Day, Halloween, ect) without bonuses or incentives. If you get low cenus you are expected to be on call for the the first 4hrs of your shift, also without "on call pay".  If you work at any of the Vibra of Southeastern Michigan you are forced to work all three facilities if they are short staffed and can be pulled to other locations without notice.  Lincoln park, Detroit and Taylor.....it's not like being pulled to another unit as a float nurse, they expect you to work in 3 different cities.  If you complain or refuse they find a way to fire you.  Management is all about the bottom line and do not care about nursing staff or pt care. The CEO gets bonuses every year for coming in under budget meanwhile the nurses do not have enough equiptment ( BP machines, digital thermometers, accuchecks) which are often broken or must be shared. The lack of nursing support and unsafe nursing staff ratios make me fear for my license.

pros: Decent pay and okay benefits
cons: Avoid this place at all costs.

pros:
I no longer have to work there.

If you dress nicely for work, wear a fake smile, never voice any idea or opinion about your work, and continually sing praise for the company and its leadership you can fly under the radar unnoticed. This is my suggested path.
cons:
Vibra cares about one thing and one thing only - money. They would sell an employee down the river in a heartbeat if it meant saving just one extra dollar.

They work hard to maintain a facade, claiming that they're a "nice family run business". They try to awe candidates by telling them they could run across the CEO in the hallway and he might say hello.

I've watched managers yell at employees in full public view. Multiple employees in leadership positions will actively & regularly undermine and disregard your ideas during open meetings - they will yell, talk over you and make it known they're smarter and more tenured than you; you don't matter. When complaints are raised (repeatedly), leaders are too spineless to reprimand the behavior. Instead, they wait for situations to resolve themselves (as in, wait for employees to get fed up and quit).

Anything that challenges the status quo will be met with shock and awe and you'll quickly make their naughty list. They continually pat themselves on the back about how well everything is running and how amazing they are.

They will overload you with more work than any human is capable of, continually changing the scope of work. Then, they'll question why you haven't finished. They won't listen when you repeatedly explain there's too much work - they see that as complaining.

They will hire literally anyone for any job, no matter how unqualified you are. Then, they stand around the dumpster fire in complete confusion as to why things aren't working.

My advice - do no take the bait... run!

pros: Stability, flexibility, teamwork, work hours
cons: Micromanagement, late with updated, and problem-solving

pros: The city is pretty and the outside of the hospital is pretty. It is pretty, because it looks like a forest. I saw a deer crossing the road after working the 16 hour day shift position.  I am happy I am not working there, and thus means I will not lose my license.
cons: The patient:staff ratios are unreal (25:1)l. If you work extra to complete the work that is given then you are an inept employee. The ratios are impossible to complete work on time. The Muslin Management needs to go back to the mid east (home). It is a dangerous place to work, and a risk for your license. Unfriendly management and management does not like female staff members. Females are treated like second class citizens. Also the gay staff member is treated like a second class citizen.  Management condemns staff member without seeing the amount of work that needs to be done or knowing what is happening on the floor.  Management never meets the staff member, but text to condemn. An unusual way to manage. Managing off the floor and by texting is unprofessional. During my 3 month tenure, I saw the management for 2 minutes, but received over 500 text to condemn my work.

pros: Rehab is a great field.
cons: Money driven like everything else. But this company is driven by revenue from beds filled, understaff the facility, and do not provide quality training of the staff. They focus on a family feel of staff and not quality care of their patients. Admissions lets inappropriate patients in and kicks them out without a safe discharge plan. They do make money. But they couldn’t care less about quality care and are confused by the idea of the sanctity of caring for the sick. They set you up to failand then dump you. Stick up for yourself. Don’t let them take your license!

review_title: If you value your career, stay away from here.

You will work at least 8-12 hour days if you follow Vibra’s unrealistic policies- I am in no way exaggerating- ask what happens if you have 7 referrals in the same day. There is a complete lack of support from the admin team on the LTACH, no guidance nor training either. 
The new CEO of the rehab has her heart in the right place and will guide them well. Overall, they deliver good care. Would I work there, not at this point and not for the LTACH.
cons: Zero support from LTACH leadership. Ever.

job_title: Registered Nurse, BSN in San Francisco, CA
pros: great staff, ok food, good management, great nurses,
cons: small, crowded, small, dont have time to review

pros: Beautiful facility. Looks good from the outside, however countless internal problems. It seemed as though they wanted you to succeed.
cons: Lots of red flags during the initial interview (which was long and drawn out) but kept at it due to the potential of it being a wonderful learning opportunity. Those in leadership positions (though not all) were very impersonable and seemed to practice favoritism. There was no specific training, and any training received was extremely sporadic, unorganized and had no structure. On my second week I brought this to the attention of a corporate employee whom told me I was more than welcome to put together a structured training manual for Vibra along with presentations that could be approved for all rehab facilities...... My thought, wow why isn't this completed already? Expected to perform within one month of starting but was given both time and resource constraints. Marketing trends practiced were both lacking and behind. Expected you to get the job done working part time when this is a 50+ hour a week position. No pipeline or communication as far as where the company plans for you to be in the future. Was told to skip my lunch to get the job done and that they were not sure of my investment because of my age. Don't waste giving 110% of your time to Vibra, invest it elsewhere.

pros:
Because the Rehab setting  is good,  as it puts back some of the healthcare choices into the patients' corner.  They get better when they put forth the effort.
Because there are a few good staff that encourage me to 'hang in'.
cons:
The recent CNO. He's been there long enough now to see that his Great Introductory Staff Meeting was just empty talk. Who can be called a Leader with such an aloof attitude? He only puts forth effort if someone has an issue, and then he uses the supervisors' opinions instead of getting involved and digging deeper.  Otherwise, he shows no involvement in his staff other than the perfunctory smile. No recognition . (sorry but the "Recognition Board" has had enough dubious names that I'm pretty sure these are hand picked).  The former CNO wasn't perfect but at least we knew he just wasn't working for a paycheck.
Full time staff is seriously dwindling, and with shortages on the schedule, who would want to pick up extra shifts with this atmosphere?

pros: Vibra purchased the physician-owned hospital I worked for. After the acquisition, the hopital finally acheived its JCAHO accredidation.
cons: The Vibra executives are very cold and brash. Upon terminating several managers, after the acquisition, they sent contract employees that were very ill-equipped to perform the job's functions. It resembled being baby sat. These contract people literally had never performed any of the job functions they were placed there to do. It was laughable in meetings to hear them attempt to contribute anything meaningful. Not long afyer the acquisition, we learned that a couple of these individuals were close friends with Vibra's COO and that was how they got the job. The CEO of the company, Stanley, has quite a way with his emails in all caps. This is his way of intimidating you...I guess. He was quick to fire off these "nasty grams" wanting to know why the census is so low.

pros: Good experience in acute care
cons: Understaffed, over worked, unsafe patient to nurse ratio, management is uncaring and suffers burnout themselves. Too many new graduates and not enough experienced nurses which leaves untrained nurses to train untrained nurses. Not a safe practice. Also pays less then minimum which is why there are more new grads then experience.

pros: Pay, location, food, and patients
cons: List of unacceptable working conditions,The leadership of Vibra does not care about nursing or its respiratory therapists. Management is allowed to micro-manage their employees until many of them just leave. If you like to be texted multiple times all day and be told on how to manage the ventilator this job will be for you. I would strongly advice not working for  this company. Their are much better places to work that will acknowledge your skills then this company. Patient care is poor.  Bottom line is a patient to Vibra is a dollar sign.The texting to the staff  is insane and why has it not stopped?

job_title: Chief Clinical Officer in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Great pay at supervisor level and above. There are some great people but many are stretched way too far.
cons: Vibra has a tendancy to not understand the relationship between patient safety, staffing and quality. Whereas all companies have to balance this, there is a lack of compromise when skilled clinicians try to address incidents occurring due to high patient to staff ratios. This company loves to "Lets try it and see" approach and then suppress the facts involving the ratios. Accreditation auditors should focus on this. You will not find any meaningful  action plans which have been implemented.

job_title: Patient Care Technician in Lincoln Park, MI
pros: No matter what job you’re hired to do, the pay is highly competitive. The money will be the only reason to stay.
cons: Always under staffed, crazy work loads. I’ve seen CNA and PCTs with 20 or more patients. Nurses with 7 or more patients, (some high acuity patients) Because of this, everybody is stressed, fighting, bickering, which causes a volatile working environment. Patients are NOT safe! Patient to staffing ratio is dangerously off. Management low censuses staff to save money. Management will not listen to employee concerns about staffing and patient safety. They always make sure you know how expendable you are if you continue to complain. Human Resources will tell other employees your personal business and harrass you openly while threatening your job.  Sick days and call off policy is a joke. No matter if you have the flu or stomach virus, be prepared to be disciplined for a call off. Do not work here! You’ll regret it.

pros: They buy lunch for the entire office every once in a while which is nice. There are some really nice and friendly people who work here that will be helpful and offer advice.
cons: There are a lot of inner groups at the corporate office and if your not apart of one then it will be hard to advance. You will have to play the politics of the office if you want to be accepted and have a shot of advancing. Expect to work a full day on Christmas eve and New Years eve. 8-5 normal work hours with some overtime but no overtime pay. The 401k isn't the best either. The company is traditional so don't expect any of the newer company benefits like working remotely from home or anything like that.

review_title: Do not go to work there
pros: Company has good benefits, pay not too bad
cons: Employees snipe each other constantly. You never know when the next backstabbing is going to take place. Reminds me of a bunch of prepubescent school children, not responsible adults. Understaffed....even visitors hear employees complain about how overworked people are. Can't keep new employees once they understand what the work environment is like, and there are bad employees that are not held accountable for what they do and how they treat others. They "sell you a dream" of a hospital that wants to be #1 in long term acute care, but that is not what you get. Can't keep management staff either.....turned quite a few over in the last few years from what I heard. Management is horrible, incredibly unprofessional.

pros: Benefits are OK. Had the day off after several holidays. Some decent people worked at this facility (Amarillo LTAC).
cons: Deceptive, immoral and manipulative management. Makes false accusations against employees and hostile working environment. Management thinks they are allowed to dictate who employees may speak with on or OFF the clock, and they tell the employees they are allowed to tell you who you may or may not text. I personally was told I was to come back to my desk immediately after lunch and could not speak to anyone out in the hallway. Texting, leaving the room and conversing with other people throughout the day was what I was accused of, but these were the actions of the accuser. I left immediately because of the hostile environment.

pros: As an employee for 9+ years, I appreciate and understand the importance in our facility and the care that we provide to the community.  We are a small hospital setting, but we have transitioned and accomplished some amazing changes and outcomes in regard to our resident success and cares.  We have worked very hard to hire a team of employees with our mission and vision in mind.  We continue to work hard everyday to be that facility that "Makes a difference" in our residents and family  lives and to provide the best care and support for them.
cons: Competing with the Denver Metro Area for successful- goal oriented patient care employees

pros: Senior corporate management has many years of specialty hospital development and operations experience.  Understands the challenges of the shifting healthcare reimbursement and overall industry trends.
cons: Vibra's hospitals are small and spread across numerous states and regions which can be a management challenge due to the diversified local and regional markets. Vibra has done a good job of hiring seasoned local CEO's and Regional Support Staff to be able to address local and regional market needs.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: For the most part, good people to work with. Pay is good, when you aren't being downstaffed.
cons: Established staff is downstaffed so the agency staff can work (making 2-4 times the money). Downstaff hours are NOT divided equally. Discipline is not handled fairly/equally. Some departments get offered bonus shifts while others don't.

pros:
Great pay for the area.

Awesome work hours (my shift was 7am to 3:30pm)
cons:
I was only there a short time and saw 4 people quit and another fired.

Management lacks patience for new employees.

Company lacks a true training program, so training will be a supervisor teaching you instead of  a real trainer.

You will have maybe 2 weeks tops to understand the job or risk being fired.

Lot of job pressure to be very aggressive on the phone.

Plenty of micro-management due to the nature of the job.

job_title: Pleading the 5th Amendment in Irving, TX
pros: Close to where I live.
cons: Management is never held accountable, turns problem's out on to floor employees. Great favoritism within no matter how hard you work or how dependable you are. Ones efforts are never appreciated. Speaking from experience of nearly 3 years since office has been open.

pros: Great to work in a small hospital environment and have the opportunity to gain experience there that would be more difficult to obtain in a larger setting. The small hospital vibe allows co-workers to really bond and creates a family like atmosphere.
cons: Lack of clinical leadership and oversight, poor staff ratios, hire un/underqualified staff to keep expenses low. Managers with HR issues tend to get promoted rather than removed. Low salaries. Too much focus on financials and not enough on adequate patient care.

job_title: Director of Business Development in Denver, CO
pros:
Innovative company.  Vibra provides a niche for  chronically, critically ill patients who require an extended hospital stay.  The staff are experts at ventilator weaning and managing complex wounds.   
Caring for the sickest patients with the most traumatic circumstanses can be very rewarding, especiallly when you se the miracles.
cons: Because the patients are so ill and the families have experience so much illness related stress it can be challenging at times.

job_title: Nursing Supervisor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Many care staff really tried to cover each other due to the high patient to staff ratios.  Had a great CNO, who really tried to change things for the better.
cons: High patient to staff ratios. High number of medical errors. Administration doesn't care and gives lip service. The recent CNO was let go because he was trying to fix things and really cared for the patients and floor staff. That was a huge mistake.

pros: The wonderful people and patients you get to meet. Flexibility in schedules
cons: Unorganized and unstable leaders. Unrealistic goals and admission requirements. For profit organization so money is always the priority which in some aspect takes away from patients. Lack of accountability. Old outdated policies.

pros: Healthcare benefits, cell phone discount
cons: No training. No bonus. Employees private business broadcasted to colleagues.

review_title: TERRIBLE. If you can hire on at our local, reputable hospitals- DO IT.
pros: Night shift diff is better than average at $7.00/hr/diff. Very close to home, I met a now very good friend there,
cons: Terrible nurse:pt ratio. ALWAYS understaffed leaving the nurses to take on even more. This is a very high acuity hospital and while you can, and will, gain excellent experience to take elsewhere, this place is a risk on your license - and they know it. Very HIGH turnover rate for nurses as once the newer RN's gain a year there, they hit the door running to a more reputable hospital. Extremely stressful and lacking adequate staff for the above reasoning.

review_title: Good place overall, but very difficult work and pace
job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant in Redding, CA
pros: Most staff is very helpful, friendly and fun work environment, work can be enjoyable and rewarding if you make it.
cons: Almost all the patients are very high acuity and we're usually staffed to 10-12 patients per CNA. This is quite a heavy load (especially on day shift) considering the acuity level of patients and all of the tasks that need to be performed by the CNA.

pros: The staff who work here really care for the residents.  They support each other and feel like family.
cons: Very poor management support.  Poor morale because there is always a feeling that someone is looking over your shoulder, waiting for you to mess up, so they can write you up.

pros: There are a handful of pros. Vibra CBO has great hours, good pay, casual dress, fair PTO, and an okay yearly merit increase
cons: Lack of communication, upper management unprofessional (talk badly about employees), unrealistic expectations, honest/hard workers go unrecognized

job_title: IT Service Desk Analyst in Mechanicsburg, PA
pros: Pay was good. I learned a lot. Most of the people were nice. Definitely NOT a bad place to work.
cons: They operated the Service Desk with a skeleton crew 24/7 so scheduling time off was a huge hassle. We had the capability to work remotely with no impact to the business, but no matter what they wanted us in the office, even if it was just two of us in the off hours. Family emergencies didn't seem to matter to them.

review_title: If I could give zero stars, I would.
pros: I enjoyed working with some of the people. I also enjoyed helping some of the patients and their families.
cons: I could name a lot of things, but it won't change anything about the environment. While I did enjoy working with some people, overall it was a toxic work environment. They take advantage of your trust in them. There is little to no accountability held, integrity or character. This includes upper management. If you work here, know that the interview is vague and they will try to take advantage of you. Numbers are key here. Not patient care or the health and wellness of employees. Trust no one.

review_title: Committed & helpful management, quality pt care
pros: Our brand new CEO is so relateable and knowledgeable! The new CCO is a go getter! There is a committment by mangement to improve every aspect of the care for the Vibra patients. This new team is just what Vibra needed, and the work environment is focused on quality for both patients and employees.
cons: sometimes short staffed, but not often...

pros: Pros- can take family member to better hospital. Write corp office and ask for changes in senior Management!!
cons: CEO lack of state knowledge and lack of ability maintain a safe patient environment.    Rude to employees and family members and like to throw her weight and title around to family members.

pros: Just being a local facility sightly different that the other two main hospitals in town. Was the go to place for employees leaving the other 2 main hospitals in town.
cons:
No leadership "Top to Bottom"
No direction "Top to Bottom"
Consolidation of job roles 
Employees being managed by supervisors that don't know they're employees job. To many middle men that slowed and complicated things
No corporate direction. NONE!

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Portland, OR
pros: Great co-workers, flexible management and 12 hour shifts beats 8 everyday.
cons: This place works you hard! The state regulations set a lower staff to patient ratio because of it being a specialty hospital. That means there's always a ton of work to do, breaks and rest are always hard to get and make you feel like you're abandoning something.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros: Although there really isn't any pros to this place, I did enjoy seeing the same patient population week after week. LTAC could be a great place to work and learn, just not VIBRA.
cons: Case load is extremely high, too few nurses, too few CNAs. C-DIFF rampant!  These patients are very sick, many on ventilators, one person cannot safely manage so many. Never have the needed supplies to do daily task. RNs are expected to be the nurse, wound care, respiratory, cleaning crew, and tech.

pros: Lots of experience doing all types of acute care. Wound care, IV therapy, Blood transfusions, Dialysis, NG and Peg tube feedings.
cons: It's just very hard work with heavy work load.

review_title: If you get a weird vibe during the interview process, trust your instincts
pros: You did have some autonomy as a liaison, unless manager was having a bad day.
cons: management wasted a lot of time with one and two hour marketing meetings talking about their personal lives. One very key manager needed more training, if you got in her cross hairs once, you were good as gone. CEOs were great. Other managers seemed to have personal issues that made them struggle to be effective

pros: Frontline staff were wonderful and hardworking but terribly under appreciated, not to mention underpaid. Vending machines (sorry they make u put 20 words)
cons: High stress environment. No training on hire. Unrealistic and unclear expectations. Pulled between onsite administrative directives and corporate directives. Leadership horribly unsupportive of what it actually takes to provide the level of care they expect. Favoritism toward clinical liaison team with large bonuses while other staff are worked into the ground.

review_title: Expected to master  skills without proper and/basic training among other negative aspects of Vibra.
pros: I, at least, have a job.
cons: No work-life balance: IT travels majority of the time.12+ hours per day and expected to always skip meals and work from hotel. No per diem for meals and chided if you go to sit down eatery rather that fast food. Analysts were told that we went to decent eatery only because we were to be reimbursed and not used to going to nice places. Insulted frequently by management. IT forced to work Help Desk while Help Desk personnel gets to shirk jobs. NO TRAINING ON ALL THE TASKS ANAYSTS ARE EXPECTED TO KNOW. KNOWLEDGE IS HOARDED BY A FEW. Go lives are scheduled over major holidays. Forced to stay on site for 2 weeks. No enforcement of policies so not only abused by management, but individual facilities, as well. Informed at last minute of requirement to work entire weekend.

pros: It is a great place for new grads or someone ready to retire but just wants to work a few shifts a month. I have got a lot of great experience and feel much more confident in my skills after 1 yr. At Vibra.
cons: It's hard work, don't expect to sit around.

job_title: Patient Care Tech in Johnstown, CO
pros: The pay is decent. You only have to work 12hrs, 3 days a week That's about all I can say that is positive.
cons: They are very unorganized. Some of the employees don't like to help. The PCTs have 11-14 patients. There are only 2 PCTs on  the shifts.

pros: Above average salary for area. Now that most of the negativity has left the building a much brighter place to work. Learn something new every day.
cons: Needs to create more of a positive atmosphere. Small office so not much growth potential but definitely a good place to hone ones skills.

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Irving, TX
pros: Paid holidays and vacation time. Retirement plan. Great Monday though Friday work hours,  Paid training. Occasional free lunch. Secured work environment. Casual dress
cons:
Management has no trust in their employees. Micro management is king
Changes made almost daily without any input from employees and sometimes without all management staff being notified.

review_title: While I loved my co-workers, the management in this system is just flawed.
pros: Good co-workers, complex and challenging patients,  a sense of accomplishment in helping patients get home.
cons: Difficulty getting time off, micromanagement, favoritism by management, more and more added to our responsibilities, facility needs updating as well as equipment

job_title: Anonymous Employee in San Diego, CA
pros: Quality care. Empathetic floor staff. VERY clean rooms and common areas. Very attentive physicians. State of the art ICU unit with knowledgeable staff.
cons: Employees complain openly of being overworked and under appreciated. Location prone to loud noises at night (ambulances, emergency vehicles). Confusing entry and layout with inadequate signage.

pros: no real pros except that if you're desperate, and I mean DESPERATE, for a job, then here's your last resort, they'll hire ANYONE! The pay is not worth what you would expect. The only pros I could think of is that the union is in talks to move in so there might start being some better equality. And it's a job.
cons:
Where to start: how about the fact that they are short staffed on a daily (and nightly) basis in all categories from RN's to RT's to CNA's to Monitor Techs. And who could blame the staff for being disgruntle most of the time considering they are never stocked with appropriate medical supplies. I've had a few visitors come and complain about how she would constantly catch other RN's falling asleep at the nurses station. I know it's nights but that's why you compensate and sleep during days. The funny thing you'll notice about this place is that most of the nursing staff...are filipino. And if you're not in their "click", they will throw you under the bus the first chance they get. I've seen it done to a few good coworkers and it was terrible!!! And management does nothing in the meantime. Any chance for advancement - none. Work and Life balance - they don't care, as long as they're covered, they can careless if you've slept or not. You can come in every day they call you to help fill in the short staffing, and in return, you'll get nothing. You'll be lucky to get a lunch let alone your 2 15 min breaks you're LEGALLY entitled to but can't because, once again, you'll be short staffed! The supervisors get mad when you ask for you're lunch so if hired, I advise you to eat a hearty meal BEFORE you clock in otherwise you'll starve to death.
Another side note; they are so technologically behind. They actually pride themselves for having one of the few Oxinet machines in the area...AN OXINET machine!!!! Those things are so outdated, most facilities are not even using them anymore because of how obsolete they have become! I thought the hiring manager was joking when she told me this...then when i went on the tour, i had to refrain myself from laughing when i saw it still there. 
There have been numerous times when I've seen patients laying in bed...filled with feces and for hours!!! Night shift blamed day shift and day shift blamed night shift. All the while no one bothered to just go in and clean him. They took more time trying to figure out how/why this happened than it would taken to just go in and clean him up. It would almost be better that this place be shut down! I would not recommend this place for a friend or family to work or visit!

job_title: Licensed Vocational Nurse in Folsom, CA
pros: Exceptional care- All patients are encouraged to bring adaptive devices or equipment that they currently use, such as hearing aids, dentures, glasses, walkers and wheelchairs. They should be clearly marked for identification purposes. These items assist with orientation, independence and comfort during the patient stay.
cons: Work hours are not as varied. Medical staff are primarily scheduled for three days a week 12 hour shifts either morning or nights.

review_title: Apple Valley location & everyone is so nice! Lead PT is so eager to teach! It helps going into the PTA program!
job_title: Rehab Aide in Apple Valley, CA
pros: Good pay for my position! Awesome co workers! Everyone is very welcoming and make you part of the working family. They are flexible with schedule!
cons: The drive could be better but isn't as bad as I thought from highland area. Nothing really bad that I could complain about.

pros: A lot of opportunities to learn new skills
cons:
Understaffed
Insane patient to nurse ratios (often anywhere from 7-12:1)
High turn over rate

job_title: Patient Account Representative in Fresno, CA
pros: Competitive salary, ok benefits, flexible shift.
cons: High turnover, little training of new staff, socializing is frowned upon, tense environment, upper management feels invincible.

pros: Strong Clinical Pharmacy staff, Autonomy, Highly trained technicians, Flexibility, Autonomy, Strong management
cons: Small hospital, Period of transition, workload

review_title: Vibra is small size nice long term specialty hospital
pros: Great environment. Staffs are very nice, helpful and appreciative with positive attitude. Flexible work schedule.
cons: Since it's LTAC, lacks the luxury of big hospital so it  can be challenging at times but lots of support and help available

review_title: The worst facility I have ever rotated through.
pros: The only thing good was the pay
cons: Administration cares absolutely nothing about the staff safety or needs. They are willing to lie, threaten and intimidate staff. The likley hood of you loosing your liscence or state being called on you from the 400 hall is greater than you waking up to go into work.

pros: Very good teamwork by staff, great physical therapist.  A place you can be proud to work, do to good outcomes.
cons: Not enough CNAs, especially considering most of patients need help getting to the bathroom.  Also there was preferential treatment in patient assignment for some RNs.

job_title: Registered Healthcare Professional in Redding, CA
pros: Good People to work with.
cons: Unconnected Management.  Terrible Turnover Rates

pros: The pay is competitive and I have learned a lot about the characters of men and women in leadership.
cons: This company often hire's management without skills. I've worked for this  company for over a year and I find that they do not utilize valuable employees.  Those with knowledge are posed as threats and are often overlooked and suffer criticism.

pros:
Diverse patient types
range in acuity levels 
Rare diagnosis
The success stories are amazing to witness 
Ventilator experience 
Complex wound management
cons:
Limited training
Limited resources at times
Fluctuations in census

pros: The pharmacy staff are great, and they have a great new Director of Pharmacy starting soon.  Very responsible department.
cons: None that relate to Vibra itself,  It has been bought/transferred a few times

pros:
High responsibility position
Great interaction between the interdisciplinary team
Friendly staff
cons:
Requires training/guidance of the role of an RDN within the company
Over 40 hours per week required, requires 1.5 RDNs
Outdated form of charting, minimal computer use

review_title: STAY AWAY! DOES NOT CARE ABOUT EMPLOYEES
pros: Only pro is the pay
cons: Negative environment, there is nothing positive about this place. Micro management, talks down to staff, work overload, not only are you a biller but a collector as well. Disorganized, the needs of the office are always changing and more work is throw at you. This is the worst company I have ever worked for. They do not care about their employees and it shows. STAY AWAY!!!

review_title: More for cooperate people than the staff at the hospital
pros: you will learn a lot
cons: do not value there workers. Cooperate takes the cheapest easy fix which always ends up costing them more in the long run. They will never learn

job_title: Unit Clerk in Bowling Green, KY
pros: The people on the clinical side that you work with are like family
cons: Management is poorly constructed, no opportunities for advancement, if you do try to advance they shoot your application down for being "overqualified" (or just not ackowledging it), but keep you in the lower position

job_title: RN, Director Outpatient Services in Denver, CO
pros: Good salary and benefits, focused and committed leadership team, friendly employees who work well as a team.
cons: CEO and CCO are new to facility but have demonstrated their commitment  to doing what is necessary to improve our hospital!

job_title: Billing Cash Applications in Fresno, CA
pros: Benefits reason for 1 star.
cons: Horrible management. Supervisors are bullies and could care less about employees happiness. People deserve respect. They say u can go to them and then to complain about harrassment and they treat you like crap til you quit. Constantly heard supervisor speak negative about employees.

pros: They are good at hiring amazing people you will love your coworkers they love and treat you just like family
cons: Their aren't really any cons just be firm on your starting salary even if they try to offer you lower stand firm

pros: Staff gets along well. Pay is good. Able to learn a lot of skills you wouldn't at a nursing home.
cons: Bad management. Rules always changing. Morale is low.

pros: Pay is good. You get a lot of experience. Most of the people are genuine.
cons: One of the worst work cultures to be around! Management does not know how to manage their employees. The same issues that cause people to leave in a short amount of time. Bullying and authoritative work environment that comes from an individual not management.

pros: You will gain a great deal of experience caring for complex medical patients
cons: Backsdtabbing bullying .staff direspecting staff and same one doing it over and over without discipline or counseling for it

pros: Good pay PTO is good holidays off good hourly schedules
cons: The managers are incompetent the employees have more experience than the managers. They choose to get management from outside instead of promoting from within. They managers retaliate when someone question their practices worst company I have ever worked for CBO in Irving Texas!!!

pros: The nursing staff truly cares about patient care.  They are hungry to grow and develop and most of all they just want to feel valued.
cons: Everything is an opportunity from the facility administrator to the other managers below.  No consistency, favoritism, politics, and racism.  You have a marketer but evidently needs help doing the job.

review_title: Lakeway TX - New facility with exciting possibilities
pros: Opportunity to promote exceptional standards. Management has listened to our requests and have taken suggestions.
cons: The newness also promotes communication issues. None that have been critical, fortunately

pros: I like my coworkers, they are the reason I have stayes so long
cons: Nurse to patient ratio is extremely unsafe. I am currently looking for a new job. Management only cares about money, they forget that we are dealing with human beings and these patients deserve better

review_title: It have change a lot over the years.
pros: Its was a nice run been there 9 years in July but now we are contract and the are the worst company I ever work for.
cons: Hhs is they down fall

job_title: Sales and Marketing in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Great sales staff working with me, some senior leadership very helpful.  Not much else.  Vibra is not the place it once was.
cons: Individual hospital leadership, specifically CEO, all about bottom line with little to no concern for patient care or physician relations.

job_title: Clinical Liaison in New Albany, IN
pros: When goals are met, commission is nice.
cons: micro management; work becomes your life; you are responsible for too many roles at once, especially on weekends; constantly questioned about anything you do; management is not clinical;

pros: The pay is pretty good. The workload is not too heavy.
cons: The benefits are expensive and not very good. Some of the policies in this department are unfair

pros: Great experience with team player work mates.
cons: Poor administration, low wages, not enough staff to cover work load.

pros: Team atmosphere all the time, friendly staff members, accountability.
cons: Low census do to location may cause you to be cancelled.

pros: close to home, good pay
cons: poor job security, I was there for 3 years full time and had the most seniority in the entire department.  They also kept changing the bonus program which was a large portion of the salary structure.

review_title: i was the lead person in material management dept.
job_title: Materials Management Specialist in Springfield, MA
pros: great place to work great people great atmosphere paid well close to home
cons: the fact that it closed an left so many unemployed

job_title: Unit Secretary in San Diego, CA
pros: Friendly, caring nurses.  Try really hard to give good service to community.
cons: Lack of modern equipment.  Need inservice, needs educator.

job_title: RN, Nurse Supervisor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Good pay for the area
cons: Short staffed majority of time.  Many nurses don't have the skills or knowledge to be able to care for patient population.

review_title: Vibra Hospital - Mahoning Valley (Boardman & Warren, OH)
pros:
Regional CEO
Facility CEO and CCO
Management
Clinical Staff 

All parties above really care about patient outcomes.
cons:
Census fluctuates.
High turnover rate (seems to be stablizing at this facility).

review_title: Good employer who met my needs and goals.
pros: Very fair employer.  Had an excellent supervisor.
cons: Needs to improve its 401k plan by increasing the match money.

pros: 12 hr shifts 36 hr full time bonuses for extra days. good support.  Nice nursing staff.
cons: five pt per nurse extremely busy all through the night a lot of charting.

pros: Good clinical experience. Floor staff is great team to work with.
cons: Poor management, unreliable hours with frequent call-offs due to them constantly hiring.  Short-staffed on the floor because they do not staff reflecting acuity.  Unsafe patient ratios. Pharmacy is poorly managed, and is difficult to work with. Schedule is all over the place.

job_title: Registered Nurse in San Diego, CA
pros: Great nurses and multidisciplinary team. Up and coming hospital.
cons: Frequently short-staffed, high staff turnover, company and management undergoing many changes, very high-actuity patients.

pros: Everyone gets a chance to be employee of the month they just pull employees name out of a hat each month.
cons:
No team work, dangerous work environment, toxic atmosphere
Bad management, no experienced staff including charge for the very sick pts there

pros: Great location. Good benefits and pay.
cons: High employee turn around with difficult and preoccupied management. Poor training due to rush in filling open positions.

job_title: Clinical Liaison in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros: The job itself was fun.  They pay well.
cons: They took a fun job and made it awful. No amount of pay is worth the abuse you take from upper management.  It’s a toxic work environment with no respect for their employees.  It’s all about their bottom line.

pros: excellent nursing staff and that is about it.  nurses work very hard for what they get and that is very low pay
cons: go through management faster than i can change my underwear....  management is very poor and have no consistency.  shame on you guys....

job_title: Medical Technologist in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros: They offer flexible work hours
cons: low compensation, constant change efforts by administration, under-staffed, very little upward movement opportunities.

pros: Benefits and vacation are adequate
cons: Lots of  restructuring and layoffs

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Boise, ID
pros: Great team of nurses, CNAs, RTs and therapy team.
cons: Almost constant turnover because of unrealistic/unsafe staffing. Constant change in management.

pros: Salary is above average for employees
cons: nothing that I can think of

job_title: Registered Nurse in Mount Pleasant, SC
pros: There are caring staff members, and they shine even brighter in an organization fraught with dysfunction.
cons: Absolutely incompetent management. There almost seems to be a pathological nature to the administrative and managerial hiring process. Incapable of handling even the simplest of tasks, and first ones out of the door at 3 pm.

job_title: Unit Clerk in Lincoln Park, MI
pros: Great wages, free soda pop, nice people on night shift!
